016package squidpony.squidmath;
017
018import squidpony.annotation.GwtIncompatible;
019
020import java.math.BigInteger;
021import java.util.Random;
022
023/**
024 * Mathematical operations not provided by {@link Math java.lang.Math}.
025 * <br>
026 * Originally part of the <a href="http://maths.uncommons.org/">Uncommon Maths software package</a> as Maths.
027 * @author Daniel Dyer
028 */
029public final class MathExtras
030{
031    // The biggest factorial that can be calculated using 64-bit signed longs.
032    private static final int MAX_LONG_FACTORIAL = 20;
033
034    // Cache BigInteger factorial values because they are expensive to generate.
035    private static final int CACHE_SIZE = 256;
036    static final long[] factorialsStart = new long[]{
037            0, 1, 2, 6, 24, 120, 720, 5040, 40320, 362880, 3628800, 39916800, 479001600,
038            6227020800L, 87178291200L, 1307674368000L, 20922789888000L, 355687428096000L,
039            6402373705728000L, 121645100408832000L, 2432902008176640000L
040    };
041    private static final OrderedMap<Integer, BigInteger> BIG_FACTORIALS
042        = new OrderedMap<Integer, BigInteger>();
043
044
045    private MathExtras()
046    {
047        // Prevent instantiation.
048    }
049
050
051    /**
052     * Calculates the factorial of n where n is a number in the
053     * range 0 - 20.  Zero factorial is equal to 1.  For values of
054     * n greater than 20 you must use {@link #bigFactorial(int)}.
055     * @param n The factorial to calculate.
056     * @return The factorial of n.
057     * @see #bigFactorial(int)
058     */
059    public static long factorial(int n)
060    {
061        if (n < 0 || n > MAX_LONG_FACTORIAL)
062        {
063            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Argument must be in the range 0 - 20.");
064        }
065        /*
066        long factorial = 1;
067        for (int i = n; i > 1; i--)
068        {
069            factorial *= i;
070        }*/
071        return factorialsStart[n];
072    }
073
074
075    /**
076     * Calculates the factorial of n where n is a positive integer.
077     * Zero factorial is equal to 1.  For values of n up to 20, consider
078     * using {@link #factorial(int)} instead since it uses a faster
079     * implementation.
080     * @param n The factorial to calculate.
081     * @return The factorial of n.
082     * @see #factorial(int)
083     */
084    public static BigInteger bigFactorial(int n)
085    {
086        if (n < 0)
087        {
088            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Argument must greater than or equal to zero.");
089        }
090
091        BigInteger factorial = null;
092        if (n < CACHE_SIZE) // Check for a cached value.
093        {
094            factorial = BIG_FACTORIALS.get(n);
095        }
096
097        if (factorial == null)
098        {
099            factorial = BigInteger.ONE;
100            for (int i = n; i > 1; i--)
101            {
102                factorial = factorial.multiply(BigInteger.valueOf(i));
103            }
104            if (n < CACHE_SIZE) // Cache value.
105            {
106                if(!BIG_FACTORIALS.containsKey(n))
107                    BIG_FACTORIALS.put(n, factorial);
108            }
109        }
110
111        return factorial;
112    }
113
114
115    /**
116     * Calculate the first argument raised to the power of the second.
117     * This method only supports non-negative powers.
118     * @param value The number to be raised.
119     * @param power The exponent (must be positive).
120     * @return {@code value} raised to {@code power}.
121     */
122    public static long raiseToPower(int value, int power)
123    {
124        if (power < 0)
125        {
126            throw new IllegalArgumentException("This method does not support negative powers.");
127        }
128        long result = 1;
129        for (int i = 0; i < power; i++)
130        {
131            result *= value;
132        }
133        return result;
134    }
135
136
137    /**
138     * Calculate logarithms for arbitrary bases.
139     * @param base The base for the logarithm.
140     * @param arg The value to calculate the logarithm for.
141     * @return The log of {@code arg} in the specified {@code base}.
142     */
143    public static double log(double base, double arg)
144    {
145        // Use natural logarithms and change the base.
146        return Math.log(arg) / Math.log(base);
147    }
148
149
150    /**
151     * Checks that two values are approximately equal (plus or minus a specified tolerance).
152     * @param value1 The first value to compare.
153     * @param value2 The second value to compare.
154     * @param tolerance How much (in percentage terms, as a percentage of the first value)
155     * the values are allowed to differ and still be considered equal.  Expressed as a value
156     * between 0 and 1.
157     * @return true if the values are approximately equal, false otherwise.
158     */
159    public static boolean approxEquals(double value1,
160                                       double value2,
161                                       double tolerance)
162    {
163        if (tolerance < 0 || tolerance > 1)
164        {
165            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Tolerance must be between 0 and 1.");
166        }
167        return Math.abs(value1 - value2) <= value1 * tolerance;
168    }
169
170
171    /**
172     * If the specified value is not greater than or equal to the specified minimum and
173     * less than or equal to the specified maximum, adjust it so that it is.
174     * @param value The value to check.
175     * @param min The minimum permitted value.
176     * @param max The maximum permitted value.
177     * @return {@code value} if it is between the specified limits, {@code min} if the value
178     * is too low, or {@code max} if the value is too high.
179     */
180    public static int clamp(int value, int min, int max)
181    {
182        return Math.min(Math.max(value, min), max);
183    }
184
185
186    /**
187     * If the specified value is not greater than or equal to the specified minimum and
188     * less than or equal to the specified maximum, adjust it so that it is.
189     * @param value The value to check.
190     * @param min The minimum permitted value.
191     * @param max The maximum permitted value.
192     * @return {@code value} if it is between the specified limits, {@code min} if the value
193     * is too low, or {@code max} if the value is too high.
194     */
195    public static long clamp(long value, long min, long max)
196    {
197        return Math.min(Math.max(value, min), max);
198    }
199
200
201    /**
202     * If the specified value is not greater than or equal to the specified minimum and
203     * less than or equal to the specified maximum, adjust it so that it is.
204     * @param value The value to check.
205     * @param min The minimum permitted value.
206     * @param max The maximum permitted value.
207     * @return {@code value} if it is between the specified limits, {@code min} if the value
208     * is too low, or {@code max} if the value is too high.
209     */
210    public static double clamp(double value, double min, double max)
211    {
212        return Math.min(Math.max(value, min), max);
213    }
214
215    /**
216     * If the specified value is not greater than or equal to the specified minimum and
217     * less than or equal to the specified maximum, adjust it so that it is.
218     * @param value The value to check.
219     * @param min The minimum permitted value.
220     * @param max The maximum permitted value.
221     * @return {@code value} if it is between the specified limits, {@code min} if the value
222     * is too low, or {@code max} if the value is too high.
223     */
224    public static float clamp(float value, float min, float max)
225    {
226        return Math.min(Math.max(value, min), max);
227    }
228
229    /**
230     * Like the modulo operator {@code %}, but the result will always match the sign of {@code d} instead of {@code op}.
231     * @param op the dividend; negative values are permitted and wrap instead of producing negative results
232     * @param d the divisor; if this is negative then the result will be negative, otherwise it will be positive
233     * @return the remainder of the division of op by d, with a sign matching d
234     */
235    public static double remainder(final double op, final double d) {
236        return (op % d + d) % d;
237    }
238
239    /**
240     * Determines the greatest common divisor of a pair of natural numbers
241     * using the Euclidean algorithm.  This method only works with natural
242     * numbers.  If negative integers are passed in, the absolute values will
243     * be used.  The return value is always positive.
244     * @param a The first value.
245     * @param b The second value.
246     * @return The greatest common divisor.
247     */
248    public static long greatestCommonDivisor(long a, long b)
249    {
250        a = Math.abs(a);
251        b = Math.abs(b);
252        while (b != 0)
253        {
254            long temp = b;
255            b = a % b;
256            a = temp;
257        }
258        return a;
259    }
260
261    /**
262     * Given any odd int {@code a}, this finds another odd int {@code b} such that {@code a * b == 1}.
263     * <br>
264     * This is incompatible with GWT, but it should usually only find uses in exploratory code or in tests anyway...
265     * It is only incompatible because it tends to rely on multiplication overflow to work.
266     * @param a any odd int; note that even numbers do not have inverses modulo 2 to the 32
267     * @return the multiplicative inverse of {@code a} modulo 4294967296 (or, 2 to the 32)
268     */
269    @GwtIncompatible
270    public static int modularMultiplicativeInverse(int a)
271    {
272        int x = 2 ^ a * 3;     //  5 bits
273        x *= 2 - a * x;        // 10
274        x *= 2 - a * x;        // 20
275        x *= 2 - a * x;        // 40 -- 32 low bits
276        return x;
277    }
278
279    /**
280     * Given any odd long {@code a}, this finds another odd long {@code b} such that {@code a * b == 1L}.
281     * @param a any odd long; note that even numbers do not have inverses modulo 2 to the 64
282     * @return the multiplicative inverse of {@code a} modulo 18446744073709551616 (or, 2 to the 64)
283     */
284    public static long modularMultiplicativeInverse(long a)
285    {
286        long x = 2 ^ a * 3;    //  5 bits
287        x *= 2 - a * x;        // 10
288        x *= 2 - a * x;        // 20
289        x *= 2 - a * x;        // 40
290        x *= 2 - a * x;        // 80 -- 64 low bits
291        return x;
292    }
293
294    /**
295     * A way of taking a double in the (0.0, 1.0) range and mapping it to a Gaussian or normal distribution, so high
296     * inputs correspond to high outputs, and similarly for the low range. This is centered on 0.0 and its standard
297     * deviation seems to be 1.0 (the same as {@link Random#nextGaussian()}). If this is given an input of 0.0
298     * or less, it returns -38.5, which is slightly less than the result when given {@link Double#MIN_VALUE}. If it is
299     * given an input of 1.0 or more, it returns 38.5, which is significantly larger than the result when given the
300     * largest double less than 1.0 (this value is further from 1.0 than {@link Double#MIN_VALUE} is from 0.0). If
301     * given {@link Double#NaN}, it returns whatever {@link Math#copySign(double, double)} returns for the arguments
302     * {@code 38.5, Double.NaN}, which is implementation-dependent. It uses an algorithm by Peter John Acklam, as
303     * implemented by Sherali Karimov.
304     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20150910002142/http://home.online.no/~pjacklam/notes/invnorm/impl/karimov/StatUtil.java">Original source</a>.
305     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20151030215612/http://home.online.no/~pjacklam/notes/invnorm/">Information on the algorithm</a>.
306     * <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probit_function">Wikipedia's page on the probit function</a> may help, but
307     * is more likely to just be confusing.
308     * <br>
309     * Acklam's algorithm and Karimov's implementation are both quite fast. This appears faster than generating
310     * Gaussian-distributed numbers using either the Box-Muller Transform or Marsaglia's Polar Method, though it isn't
311     * as precise and can't produce as extreme min and max results in the extreme cases they should appear. If given
312     * a typical uniform random {@code double} that's exclusive on 1.0, it won't produce a result higher than
313     * {@code 8.209536145151493}, and will only produce results of at least {@code -8.209536145151493} if 0.0 is
314     * excluded from the inputs (if 0.0 is an input, the result is {@code 38.5}). A chief advantage of using this with
315     * a random number generator is that it only requires one random double to obtain one Gaussian value;
316     * {@link Random#nextGaussian()} generates at least two random doubles for each two Gaussian values, but may rarely
317     * require much more random generation.
318     * <br>
319     * This can be used both as an optimization for generating Gaussian random values, and as a way of generating
320     * Gaussian values that match a pattern present in the inputs (which you could have by using a sub-random sequence
321     * as the input, such as those produced by {@link VanDerCorputQRNG#determine(int, int)} or the R2 sequence).
322     * @param d should be between 0 and 1, exclusive, but other values are tolerated
323     * @return a normal-distributed double centered on 0.0; all results will be between -38.5 and 38.5, both inclusive
324     */
325    public static double probit(final double d) {
326        if (d <= 0 || d >= 1) {
327            return Math.copySign(38.5, d - 0.5);
328        }
329        // Rational approximation for lower region:
330        else if (d < 0.02425) {
331            final double q = Math.sqrt(-2.0 * Math.log(d));
332            return (((((-7.784894002430293e-03 * q + -3.223964580411365e-01) * q + -2.400758277161838e+00) * q + -2.549732539343734e+00) * q + 4.374664141464968e+00) * q + 2.938163982698783e+00)
333                    / ((((7.784695709041462e-03 * q + 3.224671290700398e-01) * q + 2.445134137142996e+00) * q + 3.754408661907416e+00) * q + 1.0);
334        }
335        // Rational approximation for upper region:
336        else if (0.97575 < d) {
337            final double q = Math.sqrt(-2.0 * Math.log(1 - d));
338            return -(((((-7.784894002430293e-03 * q + -3.223964580411365e-01) * q + -2.400758277161838e+00) * q + -2.549732539343734e+00) * q + 4.374664141464968e+00) * q + 2.938163982698783e+00)
339                    / ((((7.784695709041462e-03 * q + 3.224671290700398e-01) * q + 2.445134137142996e+00) * q + 3.754408661907416e+00) * q + 1.0);
340        }
341        // Rational approximation for central region:
342        else {
343            final double q = d - 0.5;
344            final double r = q * q;
345            return (((((-3.969683028665376e+01 * r + 2.209460984245205e+02) * r + -2.759285104469687e+02) * r + 1.383577518672690e+02) * r + -3.066479806614716e+01) * r + 2.506628277459239e+00) * q
346                    / (((((-5.447609879822406e+01 * r + 1.615858368580409e+02) * r + -1.556989798598866e+02) * r + 6.680131188771972e+01) * r + -1.328068155288572e+01) * r + 1.0);
347        }
348    }
349
350    /**
351     * Integer square root (using floor), maintaining correct results even for very large {@code long} values. This
352     * version treats negative inputs as unsigned and returns positive square roots for them (these are usually large).
353     * <br>
354     * This is based on <a href="https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/13244">code recently added to Python</a>, but
355     * isn't identical. Notably, this doesn't branch except in the for loop, and it handles negative inputs differently.
356     * @param n a {@code long} value that will be treated as if unsigned
357     * @return the square root of n, rounded down to the next lower {@code long} if the result isn't already a {@code long}
358     */
359    public static long isqrt(final long n) {
360        final int c = 63 - Long.numberOfLeadingZeros(n) >> 1;
361        long a = 1, d = 0, e;
362        for(int s = 31 & 32 - Integer.numberOfLeadingZeros(c); s > 0;) {
363            e = d;
364            d = c >>> --s;
365            a = (a << d - e - 1) + (n >>> c + c - e - d + 1) / a;
366        }
367        return a - (n - a * a >>> 63);
368    }
369
370    /**
371     * A generalization on bias and gain functions that can represent both; this version is branch-less.
372     * This is based on <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.09714">this micro-paper</a> by Jon Barron, which
373     * generalizes the earlier bias and gain rational functions by Schlick. The second and final page of the
374     * paper has useful graphs of what the s (shape) and t (turning point) parameters do; shape should be 0
375     * or greater, while turning must be between 0 and 1, inclusive. This effectively combines two different
376     * curving functions so they continue into each other when x equals turning. The shape parameter will
377     * cause this to imitate "smoothstep-like" splines when greater than 1 (where the values ease into their
378     * starting and ending levels), or to be the inverse when less than 1 (where values start like square
379     * root does, taking off very quickly, but also end like square does, landing abruptly at the ending
380     * level). You should only give x values between 0 and 1, inclusive.
381     * @param x progress through the spline, from 0 to 1, inclusive
382     * @param shape must be greater than or equal to 0; values greater than 1 are "normal interpolations" 
383     * @param turning a value between 0.0 and 1.0, inclusive, where the shape changes
384     * @return a float between 0 and 1, inclusive
385     */
386    public static float barronSpline(final float x, final float shape, final float turning) {
387        final float d = turning - x;
388        final int f = NumberTools.floatToIntBits(d) >> 31, n = f | 1;
389        return ((turning * n - f) * (x + f)) / (Float.MIN_VALUE - f + (x + shape * d) * n) - f;
390    }
391
392    /**
393     * A generalization on bias and gain functions that can represent both; this version is branch-less.
394     * This is based on <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2010.09714">this micro-paper</a> by Jon Barron, which
395     * generalizes the earlier bias and gain rational functions by Schlick. The second and final page of the
396     * paper has useful graphs of what the s (shape) and t (turning point) parameters do; shape should be 0
397     * or greater, while turning must be between 0 and 1, inclusive. This effectively combines two different
398     * curving functions so they continue into each other when x equals turning. The shape parameter will
399     * cause this to imitate "smoothstep-like" splines when greater than 1 (where the values ease into their
400     * starting and ending levels), or to be the inverse when less than 1 (where values start like square
401     * root does, taking off very quickly, but also end like square does, landing abruptly at the ending
402     * level). You should only give x values between 0 and 1, inclusive.
403     * @param x progress through the spline, from 0 to 1, inclusive
404     * @param shape must be greater than or equal to 0; values greater than 1 are "normal interpolations" 
405     * @param turning a value between 0.0 and 1.0, inclusive, where the shape changes
406     * @return a double between 0 and 1, inclusive
407     */
408    public static double barronSpline(final double x, final double shape, final double turning) {
409        final double d = turning - x;
410        final int f = NumberTools.doubleToHighIntBits(d) >> 31, n = f | 1;
411        return ((turning * n - f) * (x + f)) / (Double.MIN_VALUE - f + (x + shape * d) * n) - f;
412    }
413}
